discussion.content:
No, configuring group call pickup does not meet the goal.

Group call pickup allows users to answer each other's calls within a group but does not provide the functionality for agents to see their call queue history or access shared transcribed voicemail. Group call pickup is primarily for handling incoming calls within a designated group and does not offer the detailed call management features required in this scenario.

You need to create a new call queue to route calls to support agents. The support agents must be able to see their call queue history and the shared transcribed voicemail. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

Solution: You configure group call pickup for the call queue.

Does this meet the goal?

You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment.
You are designing a room that will be used for collaboration.
You need to select a device for the room. The device must meet the following requirements:

Support video -
Support one-touch join for meetings
Can start new meetings from within the room
Support HDMI ingestion of content into Teams
Which two types of devices should you select? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: Correct. Teams displays do not have HDMI output and Teams panels are for room reservations, outside of the room.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.
No, this solution does not meet the goal. Redirecting calls to a shared voicemail box alone does not provide support agents with the ability to see their call queue history and the shared transcribed voicemail.

To meet the requirements, you should configure the call queue to route calls to the support agents directly and ensure that the call queue is set up to store call history and transcribed voicemails.

Does this meet the goal?

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.

You need to create a new call queue to route calls to support agents. The support agents must be able to see their call queue history and the shared transcribed voicemail. The solution must minimize administrative effort.

Solution: You configure the call queue to use a team and a channel.

Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Yes, configuring the call queue to use a team and a channel meets the goal. This setup allows support agents to see their call queue history and access shared transcribed voicemail within the team channel, which also helps minimize administrative effort.

Selected Answer: A
To ensure that all users in Branch1 can make calls in the event of an internet outage, you should assign an SBA policy to the users in Branch1 (Option A). This policy ensures that the Teams clients are configured to use the Survivable Branch Appliance (SBA) for making and receiving calls when the internet connection is unavailable

choices.A: Assign an SBA policy to the users in Branch1.
choices.B: Reregister the SBA with Azure AD.
choices.D: Assign a dial-out policy to the users in Branch1.
choices.C: Reconfigure the PSTN trunk settings for the SBA.

questions.question_text:
You have a branch office named Branch1 that contains a Survivable Branch Appliance (SBA) in Microsoft Teams.

You have a Teams Phone deployment.

A limited number of users in Branch1 report that when the internet connection to the office fails, they cannot make calls by using Teams.

You need to ensure that all the users in Branch1 can make calls in the event of an internet outage.

What should you do?
